content.content: ![Heart Monitor](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/2rP1wlFs1uEwa2u8MCoUkE/76b82186fdcf9660675bc2356358817d/Heart_Monitor.jpg) Vital signs are measurements of the body’s functions. There are 3 main vital signs:[^16] - Body temperature - Heart rate - Breathing rate ## Body temperature Normal body temperature ranges from 97.8° F (36.5°C) to 99°F (37.2°C). It can be measured by:[^16] - Mouth - Armpit - Ear - Skin - Rectally ### Heart rate Heart rate is the number of times a heart beats in a minute. Normal adult heart rates are from 60 to 100 beats per minute.[^16] ### Breathing rate Breathing rate or respiration rate is the number of breaths in a minute. Normal adult breathing rate is from 12 to 16 breaths per minute.[^16] ### Blood pressure ![blood pressure cuff](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/6GIE4XtZQcYou4sSyWEW8W/425d992e6967a4802384396973306ba9/blood_pressure_cuff.jpg) Blood pressure is measured with a blood pressure cuff and stethoscope. Normal adult blood pressure is less than 120/80.[^16] Pediatric normal vital signs are below:[^16][^17] __Pediatric Respiratory Rates__ | Age | Breaths per minute | |-------------------------|--------------------| | Infant (Birth to 1 yr.) | 30 to 60 | | Toddler (1-3 yrs.) | 24 to 40 | | Preschooler (3-6 yrs.) | 22 to 34 | | School age (6-12 yrs) | 18 to 30 | | Adolescent (12-18 yrs.) | 12 to 16 | __Pediatric Heart Rates per Minute__ | Age | Awake | Sleeping | |---------------------|------------|-----------| | Newborn to 3 months | 85 to 205 | 80 to 160 | | 3 months to 2 yrs. | 100 to 190 | 75 to 160 | | 2 yrs. to 10 yrs. | 60 to 140 | 60 to 90 | | 10 yrs. to 18 yrs. | 60 to 100 | 50 to 90 | __Low-Normal Pediatric Systolic Blood Pressure__ | Age | Low-Normal | |------------------------------|-----------------| | Infant (Birth-1 yr.) | Greater than 60 | | Toddler (1 yr.-3 yrs.) | Greater than 70 | | Preschooler (3 yrs.-6 yrs.) | Greater than 75 | | School Age (6 yrs.-12 yrs.) | Greater than 80 | | Adolescent (12 yrs.-18 yrs.) | Greater than 90 | Call the nurse if the patient “doesn't seem right”, if the alarm goes off, and/or any of these:[^7][^10] - Extreme pain - Fever or chills - Redness, swelling, &/or pus - Confusion - Difficulty breathing - Very slow breathing - Dizziness - Unusual sweating - Rash or hives - Drop in blood pressure - High or low temperature - Changes in heart rate - Changes in breathing - Decrease in urine - Patient doesn’t look right __Listen to your gut or intuition.__ If no one is listening to you, speak with the Nurse Manager.[^7][^10] ## Monitors A pulse oximeter indirectly measures the oxygen level (SpO2) in the blood. The normal range is greater than 90%.[^31] ![Pulse Oximeter](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/62HmzU3IeA4QugCgOKEKKw/267477dfe9966f5d1053a8ae68e08060/Pulse_Oximeter.jpg) ![Nurse Bedside](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/6fG4qjqwvKAokC82CQssc4/e66a424bb2de3ed15ded931a1393fb0e/Nurse_Bedside.jpg) [Pulse Oximeter Information from the American Thoracic Society ](https://www.thoracic.org/patients/patient-resources/resources/pulse-oximetry.pdf) __Capnography__ non-invasively meaures a patient's carbon dioxide (ventilation) levels in expired breath. The normal range for capnography (ETCO2) is between 35-40 mmHg. It gives an early warning of respiratory depression (dangerously slow breathing) compared with pulse oximetry.[^32][^33][^34][^35][^36] Embedded content: https://youtu.be/jHZuuEAmDSE Most opioid (narcotic) drug errors, especially respiratory depression (dangerously slow breathing) are preventable within the first 24 hours after surgery by: - Better assessment of the patient's sedation level - Continuous monitoring of the patient's oxygen and ventilation levels - Early response with intervention. [^32][^33][^34][^35][^36] __Use the Hospital Plan of Care form to advocate and ask questions about your loved one.__ [The Hospital Plan of Care form](https://patientsafetymovement.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/POC-Blank-April-19.pdf "The Hospital Plan of Care form") [Guide to Medical Care at a Distance](https://patientsafetymovement.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Guide-to-Medical-Care-at-a-Distance.pdf "Guide to Medical Care at a Distance") Embedded content: https://youtu.be/fqMCt6o24Ss [Adult Vital Signs from Medline Plus](https://medlineplus.gov/ency/article/002341.htm#:~:text=%20Normal%20vital%20sign%20ranges%20for%20the%20average,%2836.5°C%20to%2037.3°C%29%3B%20average%2098.6°F%20%2837°C%29%20More "Adult Vital Signs from Medline Plus") [Pediatric Vital Signs from Chemical Hazards Emergency Medical Management](https://chemm.nlm.nih.gov/pals.htm) [^7]: Hallisey J.
